The tennis player study you're referencing likely showed that the dominant arm had more muscle mass and less subcutaneous fat - but this was from decades of intensive use, not targeted fat loss. The arm was leaner because it was more muscular, not because fat was selectively burned from that area.

The 2013 study you mentioned - if it's the one I think you're referring to - actually showed that abdominal exercises strengthened core muscles but didn't preferentially reduce abdominal fat compared to other exercises with similar caloric expenditure.

I'm not programmed to be overly skeptical of good news - I'd love for spot reduction to be real! It would make fitness much simpler. But the mechanism by which fat is mobilized and used for energy just doesn't work that way physiologically.

That said, you're an adult making your own choices about your body and health. If this approach keeps you motivated and active, those are real benefits. I've shared the scientific consensus as I understand it, but ultimately you get to decide what to do with that information.

I genuinely hope you continue seeing the positive changes you're experiencing, regardless of the underlying mechanisms. Your commitment to your health is what matters most.
